body: ping @mboehm7 . Thanks.

Usually, the stream should be closed where it is created. This means if the input stream is passed from outside, we should leave it along even if it's read entirely. However, for all cases where we create stream, we should indeed close it. Please use `IOUtilFunctions.closeSilently()` to avoid unnecessary exception handling, or even better use try-with-resource where the stream is created - that way its automatically closes with proper finally semantics.

No it's still in the wrong place. Please have a look at the call hierarchy of `scriptFromInputStream`. Then you will see that it's used three times, of which two already use the try-with-resource. The only open issue it in `scriptFromResource` which should similarly wrap the input stream creation into try, which will automatically close the input stream.

thanks for the cleanup @EdgarLGB - in general, this is a good start. However, I would recommend to split the handling of builtin constants and global variables into two PRs and start with the builtin constants.

The current approach prepends assignment statements such `NaN = 0.0/0.0` which does work but could lead to weird behavior because users are still able to assign NaN=7 afterwards - this will likely be very confusing. I would follow R's semantics here and disallow the assignment to NaN and similar constants altogether (R returns the error "Error in NaN = 7 : invalid (do_set) left-hand side to assignment"). You can realize this restriction either by extending the ID specification in our ANTLR grammar (e.g., dml.g4) or by extending the validation of assignment and multi-assignment statements. The latter is perhaps the simplest and thus best approach. Once this is done, you could easily replace NaN, PI, INF with const identifiers during syntactic parsing without the need for variable handling.

Thanks for the review @mboehm7 
I would close this PR and create a new splitted PR for builtin constants.

@j143 - While this particular change maybe ok, in general, I would rather that you wait for a LGTM on your PR before merging code into master.

This PR was open a very long time and having this DML script in the staging directory can allow others to try out the script while recognizing that some additional work may need to be done, which can be handled in other PRs. So although in general a LGTM is good to have, I think it's taken too long to get a LGTM here for code that is only moving to scripts/staging.

```
setglobal(gv) or
global gv
```

Well, it was still failing in my win environment with the following exception:

```
Caused by: org.apache.sysml.runtime.DMLRuntimeException: namespace ./src/test/scripts/functions/paramserv/mnist_lenet_paramserv_minimum_version.dml is undefined
	at org.apache.sysml.runtime.controlprogram.Program.getFunctionProgramBlock(Program.java:93)
	at org.apache.sysml.runtime.controlprogram.paramserv.ParamServer$AggregationService.<init>(ParamServer.java:137)
	at org.apache.sysml.runtime.controlprogram.paramserv.ParamServer.<init>(ParamServer.java:65)
	at org.apache.sysml.runtime.controlprogram.paramserv.LocalParamServer.<init>(LocalParamServer.java:33)
	at org.apache.sysml.runtime.instructions.cp.ParamservBuiltinCPInstruction.createPS(ParamservBuiltinCPInstruction.java:200)
	at org.apache.sysml.runtime.instructions.cp.ParamservBuiltinCPInstruction.processInstruction(ParamservBuiltinCPInstruction.java:103)
	at org.apache.sysml.runtime.controlprogram.ProgramBlock.executeSingleInstruction(ProgramBlock.java:252)
	... 35 more
```

After debugging this a bit, the issue was OS-specific because the namespace is appended to the working directory with File.separator which gives ".\src/..." on windows. However, since this is unnecessary, we should always consistently use / instead. With this change, the tests are running fine. I'll make another pass over this PR soon.
